布伦特原油的价格可以称得上是世界上最重要的数字。全球每天交易的 1 亿桶石油中，有三分之二的价格来自石油。买卖双方用来管理风险的数百万期货合约也是如此。一些政府使用油价来设定税率；就客户而言，取暖油和汽油价格使他们受到影响。正式称为基准的即期布伦特原油也锚定了石油以外的市场。它为能源消耗大的亚洲设定了液化天然气的价格。作为全球经济健康状况的指标，它影响着世界权力掮客的决策，从美国联邦储备委员会到中国的战略规划者。

这个已有 40 年历史的指数以苏格兰最北部岛屿东北约 190 公里处的一小群水井命名。它仍然拥有如此大的影响力是一个奇迹——而且越来越危险。价格报告机构普氏能源资讯通过观察计算布伦特原油价格的原油交易变得越来越少，这使得交易员更​​容易左右价格。因此，Platts 引入了一个解决方案：对于 2023 年 6 月以后的交付，它将把西德克萨斯中质原油 ( wti ) Midland 的交易添加到计算基准的池中，这是一种美国原油，质量与布伦特原油相似，标志着第一个来自北海以外的石油将被包括在内。实验如何展开将决定人们对布伦特原油的信任能否持久，以及这个全球最大的商品市场能否继续发挥作用。

对即期布伦特原油可能流动性不足的担忧由来已久。同名领域的产出在 1984 年达到顶峰；现在一个月只装载两三批货物。从 2002 年开始，来自其他领域的四种混合物（一种英国，三种挪威）被添加到库中。这提振了布伦特级货物的数量，促进了价格发现。它还使价格报告机构的工作异常复杂。为了阻止“压榨”（试图通过囤积货物来抬高价格），即期布伦特原油基于每日窗口期间在伦敦交易的池中最便宜的混合物的价格。但每种混合物在密度和硫含量方面都与原始布伦特原油略有不同，需要进行调整以确保公平竞争。

这些增加的措施争取到了时间，但未能解决根本问题：北海石油产量一直在稳步下降。垄断市场的活动成倍增加。能源巨头俄罗斯天然气工业股份公司 (Gazprom) 的前石油贸易主管阿迪·伊姆西罗维奇 (Adi Imsirovic) 说，它们在夏季尤其有可能，因为油井维护意味着石油产量会更少。有朝一日，对基准的怀疑可能会导致市场参与者宣布数百万份合约无效，这似乎是有道理的。需要改变来避免混乱。

超过一桶

从理论上讲，市场本可以使用比欧洲大得多的石油生产中心（例如波斯湾或俄罗斯）的指数来取代布伦特原油。渣打银行的保罗·霍斯内尔 (Paul Horsnell) 指出，为了获得可信度，基准必须在许多方框内打勾。拥有足够的基础原油产量就是其中之一，而这正是布伦特原油挣扎的地方。但有抱负的替代品有更大的缺陷。有些由单一买家或卖家主导；许多人因扭曲的税收制度、薄弱的法治和政治干预而受到损害。另一家银行摩根士丹利 (Morgan Stanley) 的前大宗商品主管科林布莱斯 (Colin Bryce) 表示，尽管尝试了多年，但布伦特的竞争对手都没有成功突破。布伦特原油唯一运行良好的替代品是跟踪在俄克拉荷马州库欣交付的wti货物价格以满足美国国内市场的价格，但过于狭隘。

因此，布伦特原油展需要继续进行。延长它的一种方法可能是将多产的挪威油田 Johan Sverdrup 添加到布伦特篮子中。问题是 Sverdrup 的高密度和硫含量会使它成为奇数。这样的增加也可能给了挪威国家钻井公司 Equinor 太多的权力。米德兰也有问题。为了使其与北海等级具有可比性，Platts 将不得不估计和调整从美国墨西哥湾沿岸到鹿特丹的石油运输成本，从而使该指数更加难以控制。但这种混合物与布伦特原油相似，最近输送到欧洲的数量激增，这意味着它很好地反映了欧盟的石油需求。

由于布伦特原油最多提前 30 天定价，米德兰的纳入从 5 月开始生效。到目前为止，市场似乎正在接受这种变化。 Imsirovic 先生指出，布伦特远期（提前购买货物）和期货（对未来现货价格的金融押注）之间的价差在健康的市场中是积极的，但已恢复到接近正常水平。当第一次讨论更改时，它已经收缩。

风险依然存在。一是米德兰淹没了基准。 4 月，110 万桶原油运抵欧洲，超过其他五个布伦特原油等级的总和。如果它在 2021 年成为篮子的一部分，普氏能源资讯的竞争对手阿格斯估计，米德兰将有 68% 的时间设定布伦特原油的价格。不过，到目前为止，美联似乎不太常被选中，这或许是因为将其纳入篮子为其创造了更大的市场，从而提升了其价值。

另一个担忧是，这种变化可能有利于嘉能可和托克等一小部分做市商，它们在米德兰的出货量中占有很大份额，而且现在可能是唯一能够追踪即期布伦特原油是如何形成的。然而，布伦特大亨的阵容随着时间的推移而演变，这表明进入壁垒是可以克服的。在 20 世纪 80 年代，欧洲曾经占主导地位的石油公司被日本强大的贸易公司所取代，而这些公司在千禧年之交被华尔街银行所取代。新面貌的基准已经在吸引新玩家。 5 月，美国企业集团 Koch Industries 出售了近十年来第一批远期布伦特原油。

最大的风险可能具有不同的性质。对布伦特原油的调整过去常常来自石油行业。这一次主动权来自一家价格报告机构普氏能源资讯，它想用自己的解决方案先发制人。既然已经树立了先例，内部人士担心结果可能是无休止的修补，不必要地对布伦特原油的稳健性提出质疑——这正是价格报告机构希望避免的结果。

1976 年，基于缅因州红色品种的纽约商品交易所马铃薯期货市场在投机者持有 1,000 份涉及 23,000 吨作物的合约未能按时交割后崩溃。过错是鲁莽地试图挤压供应，例如诱使买家以不符合标准为借口拒绝一车车的货物。投资者被烧毁了。十年后，美国土豆王子jr Simplot 仍在补偿交易对手。自那以后，没有其他马铃薯价格能够获得如此大的影响力。对布伦特原油的改造进行哈希处理会让更多的人持有炙手可热的土豆。 ■

俄罗斯在入侵乌克兰上花了多少钱？

按照历史标准，这是微不足道的数量。这告诉你三件大事

作为乙型肝炎引起的长期疾病，宫颈癌被公认为是世界上最致命的疫苗可预防疾病。大多数可广泛获得有效儿童疫苗的疾病不再威胁公众健康。但在 2020 年，即预防几乎所有病例的疫苗问世 14 年后，宫颈癌仍导致 342,000 名妇女死亡。如果疫苗接种率上升——一个有新希望的目标——这种癌症几乎可以被消灭。

95% 的宫颈癌病例是由人乳头瘤病毒 ( hpv ) 引起的，这是一种性传播病毒。 hpv如此普遍，以至于几乎每个性活跃的人都会感染病毒。大多数人不知道，因为身体会在两年内将其排出体外。然而，在某些情况下，病毒会持续存在，在女性的子宫颈上形成可能癌变的病变。

这种致命疾病是 15-44 岁女性中第二常见的癌症。在富裕国家，五年生存率约为 70%。在占宫颈癌死亡人数 90% 的最贫困地区，据信只有不到五分之一的患有这种疾病的女性能够存活下来。

如果在人们变得性活跃之前注射hpv疫苗，可以完全预防hpv 。但接受速度一直很慢。在发达国家，15 岁之前接种疫苗的人口比例从日本的零（日本在 2022 年才恢复推荐接种疫苗）到英国的 81% 不等。许多较贫穷的国家从未开始过疫苗接种活动。在全球范围内，2021 年只有 12% 的符合条件的女孩接种了疫苗，低于 2019 年的 14%。

hpv的性质会阻碍疫苗接种工作。许多国家缺乏为 9 至 15 岁儿童分发疫苗的系统，而且一些父母对为年轻女孩接种预防性传播病毒的疫苗感到不安。此外，直到诊断出宫颈癌的年龄，通常是 15-35 岁之后，才能感受到注射疫苗的好处。

但是，现在正在清除另外两个障碍。世界卫生组织 ( WHO ) 于 12 月表示，单剂HPV疫苗可提供全面保护。这将大大加快疫苗接种工作。此外，中国和印度的公司现在都在生产他们国家的第一批国产hpv疫苗。印度血清研究所计划在两年内以远低于当前市场价格的价格生产 2 亿剂疫苗。它的输出应该供应印度的第一个国家疫苗接种工作。

WHO设定的目标是到2030年HPV疫苗接种率达到90%，每年持续增长9个百分点。根据伦敦卫生与热带医学学院学者建立的统计模型，我们估计，到 2030 年，在符合接种疫苗条件的女孩中，这条途径将使最终死于宫颈癌的人数减少 265 万，与现状。如果在 2030 年之后保持 90% 的接种率，则在计算人口增长之前，可以防止随后每年接种疫苗的女孩中再有 650,000 人死亡。随着便宜的单剂量疫苗的出现，这样的数字可能不再是幻想。 ■

这当然不公平。它也不是完全免费的。但是，不管喜欢与否，雷杰普·塔伊普·埃尔多安5 月 28 日在土耳其总统选举中获胜是事实。在接下来的五年里，土耳其、欧洲和更广阔的世界将不得不与一个多刺的独裁民粹主义者打交道。这在许多方面都是坏消息：在经济、民主和区域方面。然而，实用主义者有责任在黑暗中寻找光明的缝隙。

首先是埃尔多安先生以 52% 对 48% 的得票率获胜，这一点已经足够明显，已被反对派接受。随着土耳其经济不景气和后院战火纷飞，土耳其最不需要的就是政治动荡。现在他安全了，埃尔多安先生可能至少会考虑平息尖锐和分裂的政治，他在竞选中指责他的对手与国际LGBTQ阴谋集团和库尔德武装分离主义组织库尔德工人党勾结。

与此同时，差距很小，以至于埃尔多安先生现在可能会觉得，如果他接受某种形式的妥协是必要的，他的立场将会更加强大。释放政治犯或与库尔德工人党重新对话可能会令人望而却步。不过，埃尔多安先生有可能不仅开始倾听他的对手的意见，而且开始倾听曾经与他关系密切的公正专家和技术官僚的意见，尤其是在他毁灭性的经济政策方面。他当然应该。

土耳其是世界上年通货膨胀率最高的国家之一，4 月份的通货膨胀率超过 40%（去年秋天是这个数字的两倍多）。这种伤害主要是自己造成的，这是埃尔多安先生误以为保持低利率会以某种方式抑制通胀，同时促进投资和增长的错误信念的结果。

随着选举的结束，他现在可能觉得能够向现实低头并任命一位独立的央行行长，并赋予其抑制通胀的新使命。如果他拒绝改变路线，灾难就会降临。土耳其里拉在过去十年暴跌，最近得到央行的支持。它每周花费数十亿美元帮助埃尔多安先生在选举前避免货币危机。但是钱快用完了。土耳其的净国家储备已经为负。

竞选活动的结束也可能会改善土耳其与其西方盟友之间的紧张关系。以瑞典是库尔德工人党恐怖分子和焚烧古兰经者的避风港为由阻止瑞典加入北约，这可能与埃尔多安先生的支持者打得很好。但他可以简单地断言瑞典已经满足了土耳其的条件，放弃否决权，并修补与一个组织的裂痕，毕竟这个组织也是为了保护土耳其免受俄罗斯的侵害。作为回报，西方可以向土耳其提供一些东西。一个与北约相关的问题是美国取消国会对向土耳其出售新型F -16 战斗机（并向其出售现有战斗机的现代化套件）的禁令。

如果埃尔多安先生表明他有兴趣建立更和谐的关系，欧盟也可以尽一份力。土耳其作为成员加入该俱乐部是一个白日梦，但双方可以在较小的协议上取得进展，包括土耳其公民免签证前往欧盟旅行以及延长海关协议以至少涵盖某些服务和农产品。有趣的是，法国总统埃马纽埃尔马克龙迅速致电埃尔多安先生祝贺他的胜利；德国总理奥拉夫·舒尔茨 (Olaf Scholz) 邀请他访问柏林。适度重置的意愿是存在的，至少在欧洲方面是这样。埃尔多安先生有在适合他的时候掉头的历史。这是一个他不能错过的机会。 ■

; Wed, 31 May 2023 19:00:31 GMT /内容/l6dolevrfsf26slq1gv4vevigrvmdtlq https://www.economist.com/leaders/2023/05/31/how-to-make-the-re-election-of-recep-tayyip-erdogan-less-bad-news What next for Sudan’s most notorious rebel leader, known as Hemedti?

穆罕默德·哈姆丹·达加洛（Muhammad Hamdan Dagalo，更为人熟知的名字是 Hemedti）从最偏远的达尔富尔沙漠到位于苏丹四面楚歌的首都喀土穆的尼罗河岸边的一座镀金豪宅，这段旅程难以理解。他曾经是一个卑微的偷骆驼者和小商人，一开始既没有接受过正规教育也没有接受过军事训练。然而，到 2000 年代后期，他已成为整个达尔富尔地区（该国广阔的西部地区）最有权势的民兵指挥官，掌握着苏丹未来的关键。他臭名昭著的放牧骆驼的阿拉伯同胞，被称为金戈威德，被指控代表该国长期独裁者奥马尔·巴希尔将军对该地区的非洲部落实施种族灭绝。正如一位观察苏丹的资深外交官所说，Hemedti 就像“一个从街角开始然后接管城市的黑手党老大”。

在十年内，被中央政府正式承认为快速支援部队 ( RSF ) 的金戈威德已经演变成一个拥有数万名装备精良的部队的准军事机构。达加洛先生现在是一名准将，他与阿拉伯联合酋长国和沙特阿拉伯达成了有利可图的交易，并派人协助他们在也门的战争。由于RSF控制了苏丹的金矿，他建立了一个庞大的跨国商业帝国。

到巴希尔先生因民众抗议和 2019 年的军事政变相结合而被赶下台时，达加洛先生可能已经成为苏丹最有权势的人。西方外交官与他握手；据说俄罗斯雇佣军武装了他；一家加拿大公关公司为他游说。在实际上是他自己的私人军队的支持下，他巧妙地让自己成为了巴希尔先生倒台后成立的临时政府中事实上的副总统。几乎没有人怀疑 Hemedti 盯上了最高职位。

不过现在，达加洛先生正在为自己的生命而战。自 4 月中旬以来，他的RSF一直在与正规军苏丹武装部队 ( SAF ) 作战，这场致命的权力斗争有可能摧毁中央政府并使数百万平民背井离乡。尽管RSF在过去七周内占领了喀土穆的大部分地区，并且仍然控制着国际机场、中央银行和该国主要炼油厂等关键地点，但达加洛先生仍然处于劣势。

由美国和沙特阿拉伯促成的一系列零星停火可能帮助RSF加强了在首都的立足点，使其重新武装和部署新部队。但达加洛先生几乎没有机会彻底击败军队。

尽管双方都是争吵不休的联盟，但RSF 的指挥可能更为有效。达加洛先生和他的家人及族人的亲密圈子将不得不决定他们的军队是应该投降、夷平首都，还是逃到他们在达尔富尔的据点，在那里他们可能造成更大的破坏。在 Abdel Fattah Burhan 将军的领导下，军队的首要任务是杀死或俘虏他和他的兄弟，准军事组织的副指挥官 Abdul-Rahim Dagalo。自 4 月下旬以来，两人都没有在公众场合露面。

自 2000 年代后期就认识达加洛先生的法国研究员杰罗姆·图比亚纳 (Jérôme Tubiana) 称他为“实用主义者”。曾几何时，他的主要盟友是达尔富尔的阿拉伯至上主义者。这些天他声称要为民主而战。但就在 2021 年，他与他的竞争对手、事实上的总统布尔汉将军联手，在政变中推翻了文职领导的政府。为了赢得海湾地区潜在盟友的支持，他将自己描绘成政治伊斯兰的坚定反对者，尽管多年来他一直是巴希尔先生的伊斯兰政权的热心参与者。

达加洛先生的弱点是他缺乏更广泛的民众基础。尽管他最近努力将自己描绘成苏丹受压迫群众的真正保民官，但RSF的核心仍然是一个以达加洛先生自己的 Rezeigat 部落为中心的家庭问题。自 4 月内战开始以来，其异常残暴的行为更加疏远了人们。 “他失去了民心，”苏丹临时政府的一位前官员说。如果被迫在RSF和SAF之间做出选择，大多数苏丹人会选择后者。

达加洛先生最大的收获是金钱。他用自己的黄金购买了私人和公共资产网络，使他能够从利比亚和据报道从红海对岸的国家走私武器和燃料。 Dagalo 先生还能够支付雇佣军的费用，这些雇佣军是从萨赫勒地区的阿拉伯部落招募来的。内战开始以来，据说外国战士从乍得和中非共和国来到他身边。

目前尚不清楚RSF能否打一场持久战。达加洛先生的大部分军队可能更多地是出于金钱和家族团结，而不是意识形态。尽管有零星的停火，但随着人道主义危机的恶化，他们在达尔富尔据点的战斗很可能会变得更加残酷“这是一个黑洞——我们不知道那里发生了什么，”联合国人道主义事务负责人马丁·格里菲思 (Martin Griffiths) 烦恼道.

RSF内部对 Dagalo 先生的怨恨可能会开始增长，甚至在他自己的部落中也是如此。他的下落令人费解。据说他的许多家人都安全地安置在海湾地区。 “他正在让 [他的人民] 为他的野心付出高昂的代价，”裂谷研究所的 Magdi el-Gizouli 说，该研究所是一家在该地区开展业务的智囊团。 “他们在什么时候决定不值得？” ■

; Wed, 31 May 2023 18:32:53 GMT /内容/rf8rcpdmseqlusojhipq15ldp85p9sko https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2023/05/31/what-next-for-sudans-most-notorious-rebel-leader-known-as-hemedti There is more than one way to make green steel

世界各地的钢铁制造商都希望通过改变从氧化铁矿石中提取氧气的方式来实现脱碳。这是使用间接从高炉焦炭中提取的一氧化碳 (CO) 或通过合成气（CO 和氢气的混合物）“直接还原”来完成的。

两者都会产生二氧化碳，一种温室气体。因此，据估计，炼钢约占人为温室气体排放量的 9%。因此，一个普遍的愿望是引入单独的氢气直接还原。这种反应的唯一副产品是水（或者更确切地说，蒸汽）。

聪明的。但是，Tadeu Carneiro 认为，还不够聪明。卡内罗先生经营着波士顿金属公司，这家公司的总部不在波士顿，而是在西北 17 公里处的沃本。 Boston Metal 利用麻省理工学院的 Donald Sadoway 的见解，创造了一种通过电解将铁从矿石中分离出来的方法。它的方法不是释放 CO 2或蒸汽，而是产生纯氧——这不仅无害，而且实际上很有价值。

金属与其氧化物的电解分离并不新鲜。铝就是这样制成的。但该过程使用碳电极，阳极释放的氧气与碳反应生成 CO 2 。相反，波士顿金属公司采用的阳极是由铬、铁和其他金属秘密混合在不与氧气发生反应的合金中制成的。另一个电极，阴极，是液态金属本身。

与任何形式的电解一样，在这些电极之间存在电解质。在这种情况下，它是金属氧化物的熔融混合物，铁矿石溶解在其中。使电流通过混合物既可以加热它，使其保持熔融状态，又可以将氧化铁分解成其组成元素。

这种安排比直接用氢气还原有几个优点。直接还原产生“海绵铁”，这是一种在用于炼钢之前必须熔化的固体。波士顿金属公司的工艺直接生产铁水。海绵铁保留了矿石本身的任何杂质，这意味着只能使用高品位矿石进行直接还原。在 Sadoway 博士的工艺中，杂质被保留在电解液中。这意味着铁本身是化学纯的，可以立即接受用于生产钢的各种合金元素。

依赖电力的另一个优势是世界已经生产和分配了大量电力，而制造和供应氢的基础设施几乎不存在。最重要的是，Boston Metal 的方法基于比熔炉小得多的电池。这使得电解生产模块化且易于扩大规模。

Carneiro 先生曾经经营着世界领先的铌生产商CBMM ，他认为以这种方式制造的钢最终可以在成本上与传统制造的钢材竞争，而不需要通过氢气直接还原所需的补贴、关税和碳税等支持性官僚机构.从台式原型开始，Boston Metal 现在拥有接近商业生产所需尺寸的电池。它正在与两家大型钢铁制造商 ArcelorMittal 和 Cleveland-Cliffs 讨论建立其第一个试生产设施，可能是在一家现有的美国钢铁厂。 5 月 30 日，世界银行的分支机构国际金融公司表示已向波士顿金属公司投资 2000 万美元。

如果该公司的流程起飞，炼钢的地理环境可能会发生根本性的变化。位于美国和欧洲煤田的传统工厂可能会被铁矿附近的工厂所取代，这些工厂通过连接器向当地电网供电。或者这些新工厂可以建在电力便宜的地方。 （冰岛拥有低成本的水力发电和地热发电，地处北美和欧洲之间，钢铁制造商可能会排起长队。）

诚然，纯氢直接还原在绿色钢铁竞赛中确实具有先发优势。它还受益于仅仅是对已经熟悉的技术的修改。但熟悉会滋生自满情绪。自满有时会为真正具有颠覆性的新技术敞开大门。 ■

; Wed, 31 May 2023 18:22:33 GMT /内容/su5u1l38vp2p036nn4p0pdm30n7gan0k https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/05/31/there-is-more-than-one-way-to-make-green-steel Nature holds the key to less painful injections

一个多世纪以来，使用皮下注射针头输送药物已很普遍。在过去的一百年里，我们看到了各种各样的医学进步，从抗生素和 X 射线到 m RNA疫苗和免疫癌症治疗。然而，指针基本保持不变。虽然现在有各种不同尺寸可供选择，但它本质上仍然是一个中空的尖管。

幸运的话，这可能很快就会改变。正如加州大学伯克利分校的机械工程师 Yichi Ma 和他的同事在Biomimetic Intelligence and Robotics的一篇评论论文中概述的那样，世界各地的研究人员正在寻找让针头更容易进入皮肤的方法。许多人受到大自然的启发。

一个明显的想法来源是蚊子，它们几乎可以无痛地提取血粉。一个原因是昆虫在第一次刺穿皮肤时会释放麻醉化学物质。但另一个与它们口器的形状和动作有关。

蚊子的喙尖呈锯齿状，尖端较软。这种昆虫在咬猎物之前会拉伸它的皮肤，并在将猎物推入时振动它的长鼻。所有这些都有助于减少刺破皮肤所需的力。美国和中国的一组研究人员于 2020 年发表的一篇论文发现，蚊子针头所需的插入力比普通针头少 27%。更少的穿刺力意味着更少的痛苦。

受蚊子启发的针头也可用于活检等精细操作。同样于 2020 年发表的密歇根大学的一篇论文发现，它们可以改善前列腺小肿瘤的活检。较低的插入力导致腺体本身的运动较少，确保针头被准确地引导到需要取样的区域，而不是偏离目标。

由于针又长又细，另一个挑战是将它们推入身体深处而不会弯曲或折断。例如，可能需要这种方法才能将精准药物注入肿瘤。昆虫也可以在这里提供帮助。研究人员从雌性黄蜂使用称为产卵器的针状结构在产卵前钻入木材或水果的方式中寻找灵感。产卵器由三部分组成。就像一个延伸的望远镜，每个部分都可以纵向滑动到其他部分之外。

荷兰代尔夫特理工大学的科学家们用镍和钛线束模仿这种结构，制造出厚度不到 1 毫米、长度不到 200 毫米的针头，可以在不让路的情况下穿过人造肝组织。这可以减少目前需要手术才能触及的身体部位的创伤。

还有其他想法。一种是一根针，一旦插入，末端就会膨胀，灵感来自一种附着在鱼肠上的寄生虫。这对于必须长时间插入的插管可能很有用。另一种是可以精确控制药物流过其表面的刺针。它以欧洲真虫为蓝本，包括蚜虫和臭虫。有些人可以使用微结构在身体外部引导防御性化学物质。

目前，此类设备仍局限于实验室。但是更好的针头有很大的市场。根据世界卫生组织的数据，2018 年进行了约 160 亿次注射——这是在 covid-19 大流行之前。四分之一的人说他们患有锥虫恐惧症，或者害怕针头，对于卷起袖子的勇敢者来说，贴纸和糖果上的节省将是可观的。 ■

; Wed, 31 May 2023 18:19:37 GMT /内容/39astcnd2s9vskk523tfn82k4ra054qk https://www.economist.com/science-and-technology/2023/05/31/nature-holds-the-key-to-less-painful-injections The future of fish farming is on land

北极圈以外的挪威北部崎岖寒冷的海岸通常不被认为是主要的农业用地。但在 Skjerstad Fjord 海岸的一条死胡同的尽头，坐落着世界上最先进的农场之一 Salten Smolt。不过，该公司生产的不是农作物或奶牛，而是鱼。在其 7,000 平方米的主楼内设有每年可生产 8 米长的小鲑鱼（幼年大西洋鲑鱼）的水槽。

养鱼业是世界上增长最快的粮食生产形式。海鲜约占世界蛋白质摄入量的 17%（在亚洲和非洲的某些地区，这一数字接近 50%）。富裕国家俱乐部经合组织估计，由于人口增长和收入增加，到本十年末，全球鱼类消费量将从 2020 年的 1.58 亿吨增加到 1.8 亿吨。

但海洋能给予的只有这么多。世界银行估计，世界上 90% 的渔业都处于满负荷或超负荷捕捞状态。因此，自 1990 年以来，水产养殖几乎占了鱼类消费增长的全部（见图表）。它也必须解释几乎所有的增长。

与陆上农业一样，水产养殖也会造成环境破坏。许多养殖鱼类是在河流或开阔海域的网栏中养殖的。未食用的食物和鱼的排泄物会污染周围的水域。当网栏破损时，逃脱的养殖鱼类会破坏当地的生态系统。内陆“直通式”农场需要源源不断的来自河流或水井的淡水，与那些可能希望饮用淡水的人竞争。在近距离饲养大量鱼类有爆发疾病和寄生虫的风险，这些疾病和寄生虫会从开阔水域席卷而来。 That requires antibiotics and other drugs to keep the fish healthy.

It is these sorts of problems that newer fish farms, like Salten Smolt, hope to solve. It makes use of a technology called “recirculating aquaculture systems”, or RAS for short (pronounced “Rass”). Rather than relying on a constant flow of natural water to keep fish healthy, a RAS system grows fish on land in tanks whose water is continuously cleaned and recycled. That offers three big advantages. Compared with standard aquaculture systems, RAS farms use far less water, can take better care of their fish, and can allow picky species to be raised anywhere in the world.

RAS farms are, in essence, much bigger versions of home aquariums. Each consists of a tank in which the fish swim, and a set of water-cleaning components to dispose of the waste that they produce. Much of the technology is recycled from the sewage-treatment industry.

Reduce, re-use and recycle

Unwanted solids—fish faeces and uneaten feed, mostly—are removed first. This is done mechanically, using a conical tank, gravity and a series of increasingly fine mesh filters. Most of the remaining waste is ammonia. Fish secrete the stuff through their gills, as a byproduct of their metabolisms, and too much is toxic. The ammonia-laden water is therefore pumped through colonies of bacteria which, given enough oxygen, will convert the ammonia into nitrite and nitrate. Further steps can remove other contaminants such as phosphorus and heavy metals.

The cleaner the water, the more can be recirculated, and the less is needed from outside. A completely closed loop is impractical, at least for now. But state-of-the-art systems, such as Salten Smolt's, can reduce water usage by more than 99%. Standard salmon-farming consumes about 50,000 litres of water for each kilogram of salmon produced. A RAS system might need just 150. The upshot, says Steve Sutton, the founder of TransparentSea, a RAS shrimp farm near Los Angeles, is that RAS farms “leave the wild environment alone so that [farmed fish] don't spread pathogens or pollute the waterways”.

Concentrating the waste in one place offers advantages of its own. One of the biggest missed opportunities with standard aquaculture, says Kari Attramadal, head of research at Nofitech, another Norwegian aquaculture firm, is that the waste released into the environment from standard fish farms contains plenty of valuable nutrients. Nitrates can be used as food for hydroponically grown crops. John Sällebrant, Salten Smolt's production manager, says that the firm recovers and dries fish faeces, as well as uneaten feed, for conversion into agricultural fertiliser.

Keeping fish alive in artificial tanks relies on keeping tight control of the entire system. Errors can be costly. If the oxygenation system fails, says Dr Attramadal, fish can start to die within eight minutes. But that need for careful monitoring also offers the ability to fine-tune the environment in which the fish are being raised. That allows ras systems to perform an aquatic version of what, on land, is called precision agriculture.

Salmon, for instance, prefer cold water. A climate-controlled tank is able to provide the ideal temperature at all times, without worrying about currents, tides or weather, boosting the speed with which the fish grow. ReelData, a startup based in Nova Scotia, uses data from cameras and sensors in RAS tanks to estimate how hungry fish are, how much they weigh and even to assess how stressed they are. The firm says its technology can raise a farm's productivity by up to 20%.

And because they do not rely on the natural environment, RAS systems can, in principle, be built anywhere. Atlantic Sapphire, another Norwegian firm, has built an Atlantic salmon farm near Miami, a thousand miles south of the fish's natural range. Being close to big cities reduces the distance that fish have to travel before arriving on a dinner plate. Pure Salmon Technology, a salmon producer based in Abu Dhabi, has built a farm in Japan. It reckons that lower transport costs will more than halve the carbon footprint of each kilogram of salmon, despite the extra energy costs involved in running a RAS system.

As with any new technology, there have been teething troubles. Half a million fish, or about 5% of the total, died at Atlantic Sapphire's plant in Florida in 2021, for instance, after problems with its filtration systems. (The firm describes the incident as a piece of “expensive learning” to be “seen in the context of RAS having been in the early stages of its rapid development”.)

Small fry

The biggest downside is cost. All those pipes, pumps and monitoring systems mean that capital costs are significantly higher for ras farms than for standard ones. (That is one reason why many existing systems focus on salmon, a comparatively pricey fish.) Even in Norway, where about half the country's salmon farms use RAS , it is limited to the first stage of the fish's life. Juvenile fish are still grown into adults in standard open-water pens.

Tax changes in Norway may change that, says Matt Craze of Spheric Research, a firm of aquaculture market analysts. And there are other ways to keep costs down. Some firms are experimenting with hybrid systems. These dispense with the more expensive bits of waste-management kit, but can still cut overall water usage significantly. Economies of scale will help, too. Mr Craze reckons that, while smaller RAS farms might produce fish at twice the price of standard aquaculture, bigger ones should, if they can iron out the gremlins, eventually be able to match them.

For now, though, RAS remains a tiddler. Kathrin Steinberg, head of research at the Aquaculture Stewardship Council, a Dutch non-profit organisation, says that less than 5% of the farms certified by her organisation make use of it. But with the world's demand for fish rising inexorably, that share, she says, is growing. ■

RECENT YEARS have seen a boom in biometric security systems—identification measures based on a person's individual biology—from unlocking smartphones, to automating border controls. As this technology becomes more prevalent, some cybersecurity researchers are worried about how secure biometric data is—and the risk of spoofs. If generative AI becomes so powerful and easy-to-use that deepfake audio and video could hack into our security systems, what can be done?

; Wed, 31 May 2023 17:56:08 GMT /content/9hld0oog71pmoe93uvb3gm2f4og4c15h https://www.economist.com/biometrics-pod China’s young want to work. For the government.

C hina is a land of remarkable statistics. But an official figure published on May 16th still managed to stand out. The unemployment rate among China's urban youth , aged between 16 and 24, exceeded one in five in April.

The figure boggles the mind for a variety of reasons. China is running short of young people . It is trying, without much success, to raise the birth rate. Its economic future hangs on increased education, which could improve the quality of its workers even as their quantity declines. China is also famous for mobilising resources, including manpower. Yet it is wasting large numbers of the best educated cohort it has ever produced.

Youth unemployment is puzzling, as well as surprising. It has increased even as China's economy has reopened after the sudden end of its zero-covid regime in December. It has jumped up while the overall unemployment rate has edged downwards (from 6.1% in April 2022 to 5.2% a year later). And it is likely to rise further in the next few months. This year, a record 11.6m students will graduate from university, an increase of almost 40% since 2019. They include Wang Lili, who will leave one of China's top-100 universities this year with a degree in management. “The market is terrible,” she laments. “Many graduates are very anxious”.

The number of unemployed youth (about 6.3m in the first three months of this year) is small relative to China's 486m-strong urban workforce. But they attract most of the attention, points out Xiangrong Yu of Citigroup, a bank, and his colleagues. The anxiety and disappointment felt by college students—and spread through social media—could “affect the confidence of the entire society”, write Zhuo Xian and his co-authors at the Development Research Centre ( drc ) a government think-tank.

Although the problem has outlasted the pandemic, it is partly caused by it. When covid struck, many Chinese chose to extend their studies. In 2020, for example, the Ministry of Education told universities to increase the number of Master's students by over 20%. That has created a bulge of newly minted graduates entering the labour force in subsequent years.

China's reopening may have tempted many of those who had dropped out of the job market to re-engage before firms are ready to hire them. The bottleneck has been aggravated by mismatches in timing, skills and aspirations. Some graduates delayed their job hunt last year to prepare for entrance exams for higher degrees or the civil service. But employers last year wanted to fill their ranks early because of fears of a winter covid wave. So later job-seekers missed the best recruitment months and many are now competing for the same jobs as students leaving university in 2023.

Some of them boast qualifications that are out of sync with the new demands of the economy. Platforms like Alibaba, property firms like Evergrande, and online tutors like New Oriental were once dream employers for graduates. But in the time it takes to earn a bachelor's degree, they have lost favour with the government.

China's leaders now fear the “disorderly expansion of capital” in sectors like property and education, as well as the market power and cultural reach of China's tech firms. Recruitment has therefore slowed. Only 5.5% of students graduating this year expect to go into the education and training industries, according to a recent survey by Zhaopin, a recruitment portal.

Some graduates now adopt a “spray and pray” approach, as Ms Wang (not her real name) puts it, submitting applications willy-nilly. The government is keen to steer talent into “hard tech” industries, such as aerospace, biotechnology and electric vehicles. They are promoted in the latest five-year plan and have grown faster than industry as a whole, says Louise Loo of Oxford Economics, a consultancy. Employment may follow. According to the recent Zhaopin survey, 57% of engineers graduating this year had already received a job offer, compared with only 41% of their counterparts in the humanities.

One of the oddities of China's labour market is that less educated youth are less likely to be unemployed. Youngsters with vocational qualifications or just a high-school education may have more practical skills and a more burning need for a job. “Everyone says a degree is a stepping stone,” said one hapless graduate in an online comment translated by China Digital Times, a media-monitoring website, “but I'm slowly coming to realise it's more like a pedestal I can't get down from.”

Students' aspirations may be changing. The proportion choosing to continue their studies (at home or abroad) almost halved in this year's Zhaopin survey. Students are also keen on stability and security. The share who rank state-owned enterprises ( soe s) as their first-choice has increased for three years in a row to 47%, compared with 27% who favour a foreign-financed or domestic private firm. The remaining quarter wish to work for the government or public institutions.

The government's response to record youth unemployment may reinforce these trends. The State Council, China's cabinet, has urged local governments to recruit as many graduates as their budgets allow. It has also called on enterprises to create at least 1m internships for unemployed youth, in return for subsidies and tax breaks. The offer is open to all firms, but soe s are most likely to heed the call. These initiatives risk drawing some of China's better educated minds into some of the least efficient parts of its economy.

But for young folk, stop-gap measures do at least alleviate some of the worry and confusion. Ms Wang, for example, has combined her studies over the past two years with an internship at a foreign firm. That gave her “something to do every day”, she says and also led to a satisfying job offer—in human resources. With luck, she will enjoy a long career helping China use those resources better. ■

; Wed, 31 May 2023 17:54:51 GMT /content/4q485sjfki9q3mmi5rcoq6lojk9s883h https://www.economist.com/china/2023/05/31/chinas-young-want-to-work-for-the-government Who will be Taiwan’s next president?

T HE CHINESE COMMUNIsT PARTY ( CCP ) has never ruled Taiwan. But how to deal with it and its insistence on eventual unification with the island has always been the central issue in Taiwan's politics. As campaigning begins for the presidential elections due next January, the stakes are especially high. Almost every day, China sends fighter jets into the Taiwan Strait, often crossing Taiwan's de facto maritime border; America is expanding its military bases and stepping up exercises with allies across the Indo-Pacific. The next president will take office with the island at the centre of a bubbling superpower showdown .

Already, as always, the two main parties are attacking each other for provoking or appeasing Beijing. The “appeaser”, the main opposition Nationalist Party, known as the Kuomintang or KMT, calls the election a choice between “war or peace”. The “provoker”, the ruling Democratic Progressive Party ( DPP) , says it is a choice between “democracy or autocracy”. The parties have competing visions of how best to protect the island. The DPP proposes forging alliances with other democracies; the KMT wants to talk to the cCP.

Unusually, a third-party candidate, Ko Wen-je of the Taiwan People's Party ( TPP ), may also be a serious contender. In the past, Taiwan's voters tended to split on identity lines. The KMT' s origins were as the party of Mandarin-speaking mainlanders, who fled China as the CCP won its civil war in the 1940s, and their descendants. The DPP ’s were as the party of the native-Taiwanese majority, many of whose members wanted formal independence from China. Now, more than half of voters are not committed to either party; 40% of those in their 20s claim to be neutral.

The DPP ’s candidate is Lai Ching-the, the vice-president, a softly-spoken former doctor. He is leading in the polls, with about 30% support, but is haunted by past statements. In 2017 he called himself a “Taiwanese independence worker”, antagonising China and providing an uncomfortable reminder to America of Taiwan's first DPP president, Chen Shui-bian (2000-08), whose talk of independence unsettled American negotiations with China.

Mr Lai knows he needs to tone down his language. He has said his priority is not taidu , Taiwan independence, but taizhu , Taiwan democracy, and has moderated the DPP' s slogan from “resist China and protect Taiwan” to “peacefully protect Taiwan”. He promises to stick to the careful dictum of the current president, Tsai Ing-wen, that, since Taiwan is already independent, it needs no further declarations. But all that is unlikely to wash with the cCP, which will continue to threaten and seek to isolate Taiwan as long as the DPP is in charge—fuelling the KMT ’s criticism that the DPP makes Taiwan unsafe.

The DPP also has an image problem at home. It grew out of opposition to the KMT ’s four decades of one-party rule. Its founders were activists seeking both democracy and independence. Ms Tsai's elections in 2016 and in 2020 both followed student movements in Taiwan and Hong Kong that drew voters to the DPP as a symbol of resistance to Chinese authoritarianism. But after eight years in power, its oppositionist credentials have faded. Many young people see the DPP as the “establishment”. At a recent campaign event, a student asked Mr Lai how he planned to change the DPP ’s “habitual arrogance”.

The KMT has chosen a candidate it hopes will counter its own establishment image. Hou Yu-ih, a burly, calm-seeming former cop, is a moderate with a reputation for efficiency and, in the words of a former DPP legislator, a “Taiwanese flavour”. He won re-election as the mayor of New Taipei City last year with a wide margin. He is said to speak Taiwanese better than he speaks Mandarin. The KMT hopes he will appeal to voters outside the party's traditional base.

That will depend on his cross-Straits policy, which is so far vague. Mr Hou has said Taiwan should not be a “pawn of larger nations”, adding that he means both China and America. He has stuck to generalities, like rejection of “one country, two systems”, China's discredited model for Hong Kong. Mr Hou “has been able to persuade people that he is everything to everyone,” says Nathan Batto of Academia Sinica, a Taiwanese research outfit. But the campaign will soon force him to clarify his approach to China—which will make or break his chances of winning.

Then there is Mr Ko, a former mayor of the capital and founder of the tPP. Mr Ko, who says he has Asperger's syndrome, has a blunt, sometimes awkward, way of speaking. His campaign focuses not on relations with the mainland but on domestic concerns like energy and housing, which has proved popular. In recent polls Mr Ko has hovered just a few points behind the KMT' s candidate, on more than 20%.

Mr Ko says he offers a “third choice” for voters between provoking China, and deferring to it. In fact his policies have been closer to the KMT' s. As Taipei's mayor he oversaw annual forums between Taipei's and Shanghai's city governments. He once told Shanghai officials that the two sides of the Taiwan strait are “one family”, alienating DPP supporters. Critics accuse him of being under CCP influence. Supporters say Mr Ko is “extremely pragmatic”. At a recent campaign event, Liang Jih-chang, a student who plans to vote for Mr Ko, agreed, pointing by way of illustration to his ability to engage Shanghai officials.

The TPP ’s popularity makes Taiwan's elections far less predictable. The polls show Mr Lai in the lead, with Mr Ko and Mr Hou vying for second place. If Mr Ko and Mr Hou team up, as some of their parties' representatives have suggested is possible, they may overturn DPP rule. That might lead to a superficial easing of tensions in the Taiwan Strait. But it would slow the advance neither of China's military build-up nor of its contest with America. Taiwan's would-be presidents all promise a way to peace. Sadly, it is not entirely within their power. It, too, depends on China. ■

; Wed, 31 May 2023 17:27:49 GMT /content/l8qisr28vaftqnebgj1nahosfc24a6tt https://www.economist.com/asia/2023/05/31/who-will-be-taiwans-next-president Britain’s new political sorcerer: the Reform Fairy

T heresa May , a former prime minister, was an underappreciated wordsmith. “Brexit means Brexit” was magisterial in its circularity. “No deal is better than a bad deal” stuck around long after she no longer agreed with it. Of all the phrases she popularised, the most potent was: “There isn't a Magic Money Tree.”

Mrs May's Magic Money Tree explains why no politician can pledge to spend money without saying exactly where the cash would come from. Rishi Sunak , the Conservative prime minister, has long denied the tree's existence. When Rachel Reeves became Labour's shadow chancellor in 2021, she swung an axe at it, too. “I don't believe there is a Magic Money Tree,” she said in one of her first big interviews after taking the job.

No such rules apply when it comes to reform rather than spending. Both main parties agree that although the British state requires a total overhaul, it does not need much more cash. In its bid to move away from the Magic Money Tree, British politics has fallen under the spell of another mythical being: the Reform Fairy. The Magic Money Tree could generate cash at will; the Reform Fairy can apparently improve public services without spending political or financial capital.

The Reform Fairy flutters over the National Health Service ( nhs ). Both parties think that the nhs , the biggest chunk of state spending, is glaringly inefficient and that pumping cash into long-term health rather than emergency care would be a fine thing. There is a problem, however. Making fat people thin will help in the long term but it will not reduce A&E demand next year. Plugging the £10bn ($12.4bn) backlog of capital investment has to come from elsewhere in the health budget without extra funding. Training more doctors will lessen the expense of using agency workers to fill gaps in hospital rotas, but medics will not arrive fast. All require money, unless the Reform Fairy flaps its wings.

People believe funny things when they are desperate. Whoever wins the next election will govern against a miserable economic backdrop. The last time Labour entered office from opposition, the economy was flying. Average growth was about 3%. National debt was 37% of gdp . It was in this context that Sir Tony Blair and Gordon Brown tried, with mixed success, to overhaul Britain's public services. This time the Conservatives are passing on a rotten inheritance. The economy is expected to be crawling along at 1.8%; debt is already at 99% of gdp . In such circumstances, faith in the supernatural becomes almost rational.

“Every time a child says, 'I don't believe in fairies,' there is a fairy somewhere that falls down dead,” wrote JM Barrie in “Peter Pan”. Likewise, for some Labour mp s, reform is simply a matter of belief. In general Labour hopes good intentions will be enough, whether it be reforming Whitehall or improving the country's deal with the eu . But each government enters office promising to overhaul the civil service—and each leaves it grumbling that “Yes, Minister”, a 1980s TV comedy about conniving bureaucrats, is still a documentary. When it comes to the eu the Labour Party assumes that not being the Conservatives will be enough to win favours from Brussels. The Reform Fairy speaks fluent French.

One area of reform where at least Labour has been fiscally realistic is on the green transition. Labour has pledged to spend £28bn a year (about 1% of gdp ) on capital investment to fund everything from home insulation to tree-planting. Making the national grid carbon-free by 2030 will not come cheap. The £28bn is, however, an area where discipline in the party breaks down. For some it is an untouchable pledge; for others, it is to be cast aside if things look a bit tight. If a Labour-controlled Treasury will not cough up, the Reform Fairy will have to do its thing for the climate.

Not believing in the fairy is, apparently, deadly. “If the NHS doesn't reform, it will die,” says Wes Streeting, the shadow health secretary. It is as easy to say as it is absurd. In public policy, things do not die—they simply become worse. Not changing things is always an option. Pressure rarely leads to good policy in any case. In 2010 the Tories did have a radical reform agenda but it was just as reliant on magical thinking. At the heart of austerity was the idea that cutting government departments by up to 40% would leave them more efficient, since they would cut waste. It did not work.

Today, although practically every Conservative mp agrees the state needs reform, the government shows little willingness to do much about it. Backbench Tory mp s dream of sweeping, painless post-Brexit reforms that would overhaul everything from procurement to financial regulation. Mr Sunak once believed in the Reform Fairy. During his leadership pitch, he promised to shred eu legislation (with reams of paperwork put through a shredder for good measure in one campaign video). Reality intervened. Now the Houses of Parliament are filled with thumb-twiddling mp s, waiting for a legislative agenda that will never arrive.

Clap your hands if you believe in structural reforms

If Labour is to have more success, it must learn from a Conservative government that did manage to overhaul Britain. Margaret Thatcher is associated with a supply-side revolution that shook the state and broke Britain's unions. But it took both strategy and spending. Before Thatcher smashed the miners, she had to pay the police. As one of her first acts in office she handed the police a pay rise of 45%, on the ground that broke cops would not break strikes. While in opposition, Thatcher planned: she picked allies, identified enemies and worked out where the cash would come from.

Believing in the Reform Fairy has served Labour well so far. A cautious approach on fiscal matters means that Labour is now more trusted on the economy than the Conservatives. Promising reform, rather than spending, is a way of appearing sensible. Yet promising reform without admitting that it will cost money and cause political pain is fundamentally unserious. The Magic Money Tree may not exist. Nor does the Reform Fairy. ■
